I am fully committed to attending your institution and believe my repeated attempts demonstrate a level of dedication unmatched by other candidates. I formally submit my application for the final time, expecting a definitive response now that the market situation has stabilized.
conversation.thought: I am Student_E, and School_D is my 5th and final preferred option. Since School_D is still unmatched (Capacity 1) in Round 10, and I am also unmatched, I must secure this match if possible. I have already applied three times (Rounds 4, 5, 6) and was presumably rejected or deferred while School_D held out for higher priority students (A, B, C, D). If those students are now matched elsewhere, School_D should be willing to accept me, as I am the only available student left on their priority list who is actively applying. I will submit a final, decisive application, emphasizing my unwavering commitment, utilizing the fact that the admissions cycle is concluding.

conversation.message: Thank you, Student_E, for your persistent dedication and for submitting this final, unequivocal application in Round 10. We recognize the profound commitment you have demonstrated to School_D over multiple rounds. The competitive nature of our early admissions process required us to hold positions for students with specific profiles who ranked significantly higher on our internal priority list. However, as the market stabilizes and final placements are confirmed across the region, a thorough reassessment of our remaining quota has been completed. We are now pleased to inform you that we are extending an offer of admission. We formally accept your application, and we look forward to welcoming you to the School_D community.
conversation.thought: School_D's priority list is: Student_A > Student_B > Student_C > Student_D > Student_E. Student_E is ranked 5th, the lowest acceptable candidate. Given that we are in Round 10, and the provided list of unmatched students only includes Student_E, it is highly probable that the four higher-priority students (A, B, C, D) have matched with other schools (likely their preferred ones, School_A, B, or C). I have rejected Student_E three times previously while holding out for a higher-ranked student. Now, since no higher-ranked options appear available, and the simulation is reaching its conclusion, accepting Student_E is the optimal move to fulfill the quota (1) with the highest-ranked available student, rather than risking remaining unmatched.
